document.title: The Fourier transform of spherical surface measure and radial functions

para.p:
For a topological space
X
, we denote by
B X
the Borel
σ
-algebra of
X
. Let
ρ d
be the Euclidean metric on
R d
and let
m d
be Lebesgue measure on
R d
.

Let
= X
( 0 , ∞ )
, which is a metric space with the metric inherited from
R
. Define
: μ
→
B X
[ 0 , ∞ ]
by

Math.text: d * mu * r = r ^ (d - 1) * d * m _ 1 * r

para.p:
Let
S
- d 1
be the unit sphere in
R d
. Define
: S
→
⁢ P
(
S
- d 1
)
⁢ P
(
R d
)
by

Math.text: S * E = conditional-set@(x element-of R ^ d, formulae@(x / absolute-value@(x) element-of E, 0 less absolute-value@(x) less 1))

para.p:
Namely,
⁢ S
( E )
is the sector subtended by the set
E
.
S
- d 1
is a metric space with the metric inherited from
R d
, and if
E
is an open set in
(
S
- d 1
,
ρ d
)

⁢ S
( E )
is an open set in
R d

∈
E α

(

Math.tex: S\left(\bigcup E_{\alpha}\right)=\bigcup S(E_{\alpha}),\qquad S\left(\bigcap E% _{\alpha}\right)=\bigcap S(E_{\alpha}),
Math.text: formulae@(S * union@(E _ alpha) = union@(S * E _ alpha), S * intersection@(E _ alpha) = intersection@(S * E _ alpha))

para.p:
and for
∈
E , F
⁢ P
(
S
- d 1
)
,

Math.text: S * (E set-minus F) = S * E set-minus S * F
S * B _ (S ^ (d - 1)) subset-of B _ (R ^ d)

para.p:
We define

σ

B
S
- d 1

by

Math.text: formulae@(sigma _ (d - 1) * E = (d cdot m _ d) * S * E, E element-of B _ (S ^ (d - 1)))

para.p:
For
: f
→
R d
C
and
∈ γ
S
- d 1

f γ
→
( 0 , ∞ )
C

Math.text: formulae@(f ^ gamma * r = f * r * gamma, r element-of open-interval@(0, infinity))

para.p: The following is proved in Stein and Shakarchi. 1 1 footnote 1 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Real Analysis, p. 280, Chapter 6, Theorem 3.4.

p.text:

)

σ
-almost all

we have

f γ
⁢
L 1
(
( 0 , ∞ )
, μ )

Math.text: gamma maps-to ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(f ^ gamma * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)

p.text:
belongs to
⁢
L 1
(
S
- d 1
, σ )
, and (iii)

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ d))@(f * x * differential-d@(m _ d) * x) = (integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(f ^ gamma * r * differential-d@(mu) * r) * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma)

para.p:
For
∈ r

Math.text: r maps-to (integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(f _ r * gamma * differential-d@(sigma) * sigma)
(integral _ (R ^ d))@(f * x * differential-d@(m _ d) * x) = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(f _ r * gamma * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma) * differential-d@(mu) * r)

section.title: 3The Fourier transform of spherical surface measure

para.p:
For real
> ν
-
1 2
,

Math.text: formulae@(J _ nu * s = ((s / 2) ^ nu / (Gamma * (nu + 1 / 2) * square-root@(pi))) * ((integral _ (- 1)) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * s * x) * (1 - x ^ 2) ^ (nu - 1 / 2) * differential-d@(x)), s element-of R)

para.p:
One checks that
J ν
satisfies

Math.text: formulae@(J _ nu * (- s) = e ^ (i * pi * nu) * J _ nu * s, s element-of R)

para.p:
We remind ourselves of spherical coordinates for
S
- d 1
. The Jacobian of the transformation

Math.text: gamma _ 1 = cosine@(phi _ 1)
gamma _ 1
absent = cosine@(phi _ 1)
gamma _ 2 = sine@(phi _ 1) * cosine@(phi _ 2)
gamma _ 2
absent = sine@(phi _ 1) * cosine@(phi _ 2)
gamma _ 3 = sine@(phi _ 1) * sine@(phi _ 2) * cosine@(phi _ 3)
gamma _ 3
absent = sine@(phi _ 1) * sine@(phi _ 2) * cosine@(phi _ 3)
gamma _ (d - 1) = sine@(phi _ 1) * sine@(phi _ 2) * sine@(phi _ 3 * cdots) * sine@(phi _ (d - 2)) * cosine@(phi _ (d - 1))
gamma _ (d - 1)
absent = sine@(phi _ 1) * sine@(phi _ 2) * sine@(phi _ 3 * cdots) * sine@(phi _ (d - 2)) * cosine@(phi _ (d - 1))
gamma _ d = sine@(phi _ 1) * sine@(phi _ 2) * sine@(phi _ 3 * cdots) * sine@(phi _ (d - 2)) * sine@(phi _ (d - 1))
gamma _ d
absent = sine@(phi _ 1) * sine@(phi _ 2) * sine@(phi _ 3 * cdots) * sine@(phi _ (d - 2)) * sine@(phi _ (d - 1))

para.p: with

Math.text: formulae@(0 less= list@(phi _ 1, ldots), formulae@(phi _ (d - 2) less= pi, 0 less= phi _ (d - 1) less= 2 * pi))

para.p: is

Math.text: J = (sine ^ (d - 2))@(phi _ 1) * (sine ^ (d - 3))@(phi _ 2 * cdots) * (sine ^ 2)@(phi _ (d - 3)) * sine@(phi _ (d - 2))
(widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * xi = (integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * gamma) cdot xi) * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma)
(widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * xi
absent = (integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * gamma) cdot xi) * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma)

absent = ((integral _ (phi _ 1 = 0)) ^ pi)@(((integral _ (phi _ 2 = 0)) ^ pi)@(cdots * ((integral _ (phi _ (d - 2) = 0)) ^ pi)@(((integral _ (phi _ (d - 1) = 0)) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi _ 1 * cosine@(phi _ 1)) * J * differential-d@(phi _ (d - 1)) * differential-d@(phi _ (d - 2)) * cdots * differential-d@(phi _ 2) * differential-d@(phi _ 1)))))

absent = ((integral _ (phi _ 1 = 0)) ^ pi)@(((integral _ (phi _ 2 = 0)) ^ pi)@(cdots * ((integral _ (phi _ (d - 2) = 0)) ^ pi)@(((integral _ (phi _ (d - 1) = 0)) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi _ 1 * cosine@(phi _ 1)) * J * differential-d@(phi _ (d - 1)) * differential-d@(phi _ (d - 2)) * cdots * differential-d@(phi _ 2) * differential-d@(phi _ 1)))))

absent = (2 * pi) cdot ((integral _ (phi _ 1 = 0)) ^ pi)@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi _ 1 * cosine@(phi _ 1)) * (sine ^ (d - 2))@(phi _ 1 * d * phi _ 1)) cdot ((product _ (j = 2)) ^ (d - 2))@(((integral _ (phi _ j = 0)) ^ pi)@((sine ^ (d - j - 1))@(phi _ j * d * phi _ j))))

absent = (2 * pi) cdot ((integral _ (phi _ 1 = 0)) ^ pi)@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi _ 1 * cosine@(phi _ 1)) * (sine ^ (d - 2))@(phi _ 1 * d * phi _ 1)) cdot ((product _ (j = 2)) ^ (d - 2))@(((integral _ (phi _ j = 0)) ^ pi)@((sine ^ (d - j - 1))@(phi _ j * d * phi _ j))))

para.p: We work out that

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@((sine ^ k)@(t * d * t)) = (square-root@(pi) * Gamma * ((k + 1) / 2)) / (Gamma * ((k + 2) / 2))

para.p: This gives

Math.text: ((product _ (j = 2)) ^ (d - 2))@(((integral _ (phi _ j = 0)) ^ pi)@((sine ^ (d - j - 1))@(phi _ j * d * phi _ j)))

para.p:
With this we have, for
= ξ
(
ξ 1
, 0 , … , 0 )
,
≠
ξ 1
0
,

Math.text: (widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * xi = 2 * pi * (pi ^ ((d - 3) / 2) / (Gamma * ((d - 1) / 2))) * ((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi _ 1 * cosine@(t)) * (sine ^ (d - 2))@(t * d * t))

para.p:
But doing the change of variable
= x
cos t
, for nonzero real
s
we have

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@(e ^ (i * s * cosine@(t)) * (sine ^ (d - 2))@(t * d * t)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@(e ^ (i * s * cosine@(t)) * (1 - (cosine ^ 2)@(t)) ^ ((d - 2) / 2) * differential-d@(t))
((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@(e ^ (i * s * cosine@(t)) * (sine ^ (d - 2))@(t * d * t))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@(e ^ (i * s * cosine@(t)) * (1 - (cosine ^ 2)@(t)) ^ ((d - 2) / 2) * differential-d@(t))
absent = ((integral _ (- 1)) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * s * x) * (1 - x ^ 2) ^ (d / 2 - 1 - 1 / 2) * differential-d@(x))
absent = ((integral _ (- 1)) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * s * x) * (1 - x ^ 2) ^ (d / 2 - 1 - 1 / 2) * differential-d@(x))
absent = ((Gamma * (d / 2 - 1 / 2) * square-root@(pi)) / (s / 2) ^ (d / 2 - 1)) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * s
absent = ((Gamma * (d / 2 - 1 / 2) * square-root@(pi)) / (s / 2) ^ (d / 2 - 1)) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * s

para.p:
Thus, taking
= s
-
⁢ 2 π
ξ 1
,

Math.text: (widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * xi

para.p:
For
<
ξ 1
0
this is

Math.text: (widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * xi = 2 * pi * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * 2 * pi * absolute-value@(xi)

para.p:
In general, take nonzero
∈ ξ
R d
. Let
: T
→
R d
R d
be the rotation that sends
ξ
ti
( 0 , … , 0 ,
-
| ξ |
)
. Since
=
∘
σ
- d 1
T
σ
- d 1
(namely, surface measure
σ
- d 1
is invariant under rotations),

Math.text: (widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * xi = (widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * vector@(0, ldots, 0, - absolute-value@(xi)) = 2 * pi * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * 2 * pi * absolute-value@(xi)

para.p:
For real
> ν
-
1 2
, we use the following asymptotic formula for
⁢
J ν
( s )
: 2 2 footnote 2 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Complex Analysis, p. 319, Appendix A.1.

Math.text: formulae@(J _ nu * s = square-root@(2 / (pi * s)) * cosine@(s - (pi * nu) / 2 - pi / 4) + O * s ^ (- 3 / 2), s to + infinity)

para.p: We get from this that

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@((widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * xi) = O * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ ((- d / 2) + 1 / 2), absolute-value@(xi) to infinity)

para.p:
A function
: f
→
R d
C
is said to be radial if there is a function
:
f 0
→
[ 0 , ∞ )
C
such that

Math.text: formulae@(f * x = f _ 0 * absolute-value@(x), x element-of R ^ d)

para.p:
For
∈ f
⁢
L 1
(
R d
)
, Using polar coordinates we determine the Fourier transform of a radial function. For
∈ ξ
R d
,

Math.text: widehat@(f) * xi = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * x) cdot xi) * f * x * differential-d@(x))
widehat@(f) * xi
absent = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * x) cdot xi) * f * x * differential-d@(x))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * r * sigma) cdot xi) * f * r * sigma * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma) * differential-d@(mu) * r)
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * r * sigma) cdot xi) * f * r * sigma * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma) * differential-d@(mu) * r)
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * r * gamma) cdot xi) * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma) * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (S ^ (d - 1)))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * r * gamma) cdot xi) * differential-d@(sigma) * gamma) * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * r * xi * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((widehat@(sigma)) _ (d - 1) * r * xi * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(2 * pi * (r * absolute-value@(xi)) ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * 2 * pi * r * absolute-value@(xi) * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(2 * pi * (r * absolute-value@(xi)) ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * 2 * pi * r * absolute-value@(xi) * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)

absent = 2 * pi * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(r ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * 2 * pi * r * absolute-value@(xi) * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)

absent = 2 * pi * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(r ^ ((- d / 2) + 1) * J _ (d / 2 - 1) * 2 * pi * r * absolute-value@(xi) * f _ 0 * r * differential-d@(mu) * r)
